title: Emotional Burnout
description: Prevention and recovery from emotional burnout.
welcomeMessage: Overcome emotional burnout. Learn to restore resources and find balance between work and rest.

cards.introduction: Burnout often starts with 'not wanting anything'. Let's try to see — when did this begin.
questions: When did you last feel that 'everything is annoying'?
What changed in your life during that period?
cards.recommendation: Identify 1 event or phase after which burnout began. This gives understanding of what's the cause, not just the consequence.

cards.introduction: Burnout feels like: 'I should, but I can't'.
questions: What phrases do you most often say to yourself when you're 'stuck'?
What do these phrases make you feel?
cards.recommendation: Replace one of these phrases with a gentle one: 'Right now it's hard for me, but I'm doing what I can'. Repeat for 3 days straight. Restructuring inner dialogue reduces tension.

cards.introduction: In burnout state, you might forget about your boundaries.
questions: In what situations do you most often say 'yes' when you want to say 'no'?
What are you afraid of losing if you start defending boundaries?
cards.recommendation: Start small: in one situation per day, consciously choose refusal or break. Why: this trains resource preservation skills.

cards.introduction: In burnout, you seem to have given yourself away 'for later'. Let's return a piece.
questions: When did you last do something exclusively for yourself?
What was it? Why did you stop?
cards.recommendation: Schedule yourself a 'personal hour' during the week. Without benefit. Just for pleasure. This restores the sense of 'I exist'.

cards.introduction: In burnout, every day is like the previous one. And this pulls down.
questions: What 3 actions do you do 'on autopilot' and don't notice?
How could you bring awareness to one of them?
cards.recommendation:
Awareness interrupts monotony and returns interest.

For 3 days — do 1 action per day with full attention (eating, walking, showering). Returning to the moment reduces the effect of 'empty days'.

cards.introduction: Often burnout isn't just fatigue. It's loss of meaning.
questions: What parts of your work or responsibilities were important to you before?
What changed — why don't they bring joy anymore?
cards.recommendation: Find 1 task in the week that can still give satisfaction. Do it consciously. This way you reboot your meaning.

cards.introduction: Behavior is our anchor. Even in chaos, you can choose one action.
questions: What everyday activity calms you (even slightly)?
When did you last do this? Why did you stop?
cards.recommendation: Take 1 ritual and do it every evening for 5 days straight. Why: repetitive actions create sense of stability.

cards.introduction: Self-worth isn't a reward, but a setting. Especially in burnout.
questions: In what situations do you forget you have the right to rest?
How can you remind yourself of the right to pause?
cards.recommendation:
Micro-breaks contribute to nervous system recovery.

Introduce 1 micro-pause per day (2-3 minutes without screens, noise, and tasks). Regular reboots support cognitive resources.

cards.introduction: To burn out, you first have to 'burn' for something. Time to return focus.
questions: What's truly important to you — even if you're tired?
What can you do tomorrow to get a little closer to this?
cards.recommendation: Every day for 1 week, do 1 mini-action related to your values. Values return meaning to actions.

cards.introduction: Sometimes, to get out, you need to see yourself — not as a performer, but as a person.
questions: Who are you beyond your role (work, function)?
What actions can remind you of this?
cards.recommendation:
Role decompression restores energy and meaning.

Once a week, do 1 action unrelated to work or benefit. This is an act of restoring yourself. This returns personal autonomy.
